children.text: Andy Byers: is being recorded.
Meredith Martin: Awesome. I thought that was loud.
Meredith Martin: Bye.
Meredith Martin: Everybody ready?
Andy Byers: Everyone ready to be bored?
Meredith Martin: Bored, are you kidding.
Andy Byers: Yeah, you're gonna listen to me talk for an hour, that's the problem. The system's great, it's my voice that's gonna put you to sleep.
Meredith Martin: We have a beautiful, beautiful dialect.
Meredith Martin: And I would listen to you read anything.
Andy Byers: Can I get permission to share a screen?
Meredith Martin: Yes, of course, just a moment.
Meredith Martin: How do I give that to you?
Meredith Martin: To make me a presenter, I think. I know. Oh, there we go, multiple… there we go.
Andy Byers: Sorry, I just hit the wrong button.
Meredith Martin: Amelie, I'm so glad you're here, and I love your red sweater with your red interior vest thing. That is tight.
Amelia Acker: Yeah, I feel like red and purple are… should be combined more often.
Meredith Martin: 100%, 100%.

Meredith Martin: Not to interrupt, but I just realized not everybody knows everyone. Can we just quickly say who we are? Because I think Rebecca Kozer's here, and I don't know that any of you know her. Is that okay if we just quickly say who we are?
Andy Byers: Yeah, absolutely.
Meredith Martin: Great, okay. So, you start, Andy.
Andy Byers: I'm Andy Byers, I'm the Director of Publishing Technology at Birkbeck University of London, and also part of the Open Library of Humanities.
Meredith Martin: Excellent. Amelia?
Amelia Acker: Hi, I'm Amelia Ecker, I'm at Rutgers School of Communication and Information. I'm part of the editorial collective of JCA.
Meredith Martin: Or Davis.
Odalis Garcia Gorra: Hi, I'm Hodalis. I am an editorial assistant here at JCA and a PhD candidate at UT Austin in American Studies.
Meredith Martin: Lily.
Lily Brewer: I'm Lily Brewer, I'm in, I got my PhD with Sarah, at University of Pittsburgh. Right now I work a corporate job, but I'm very excited to be on the editorial team here, here at JCA.
Meredith Martin: Lily is the copy editor.
Lily Brewer: The copy editor, yes.
Meredith Martin: death.
Meredith Martin: Sarah?
Sarah Reiff Conell: Hi, I'm Sarah Reif-Connell, Research Data Management Specialist here at Princeton University, and then editor of C19 Data Collective, helping out with data things here.
Meredith Martin: So we're gonna figure…
Meredith Martin: Rebecca.
Rebecca Koeser: Hi, everyone. I'm Rebecca Kozer, I'm the lead research software engineer at the Center for Digital Humanities at Princeton, so I work with Meredith in other capacities.
Rebecca Koeser: I have a background in English literature and computer science, and have worked on other publication systems, so super excited to get a peek into Janeway.
Meredith Martin: All right, thanks everyone. So let's, unmute when we have questions, mute otherwise because of the Zoom, and we'll let Andy take it away.

Andy Byers: Yeah, so absolutely feel free to interrupt me as we go along, because it's much easier to answer questions while we're looking at stuff. So I'm going to take you through the workflow, we're going to start by submitting an article, then we're going to send it out for peer review, we're gonna…
Meredith Martin: Sorry, I just realized, since CeCe's not here, Haichi or Orelisse, will one of you please open a doc to take notes?
Meredith Martin: Thank you. Okay, sorry, go ahead.

Andy Byers: No, no worries. So we'll run it through peer review, we'll send it out for copy editing, we'll send it out for typesetting, and then we'll run through the pre-publication checklist, and publish a paper.

Andy Byers: And if there's time, depending on how quickly we get through things, we can start having a look at the other, areas of Janeway, so the non-publication workflow parts, the settings, and things like that, so we can look at those as well. But we have also got a meeting scheduled next week to go through those in more detail anyway. So yeah, we're gonna start with submitting an article.
Andy Byers: So when you start the submission process, you come to the author agreement page.

Andy Byers: There are 3 main areas. The publication fees, so if you charge a fee, you can put that in here. If you don't charge a fee, you can use this section to explain where, where funding for your journal comes from. So for example, at OLH, we sort of encourage people to recommend that libraries sign up to our consortial billing, model.
Andy Byers: So we have that in there. If you don't want this section, you can turn it off so it doesn't appear at all. But there is different options there. Submission checklist is your,

Andy Byers: general list of things that authors need to do before submitting, so what file format they need to use, if there's a reference style they need to follow, that kind of thing can be listed here. And it's an open HTML field, so you can put whatever content you like in there. So, we have an example here, a paragraph, and then a list, and then another paragraph.
Andy Byers: And then copyright notice, which is the important part.
Meredith Martin: Real quick, back to the checklist. So it's just a 1, 2, 3, 4, it's not actually a check.
Andy Byers: You have to agree to each… to… to the… to the…
Andy Byers: To the items in the, in the, in the list, yeah.
Meredith Martin: So the very bottom is the only check, though.
Andy Byers: Yeah, but you can't go past it without checking it, so…
Meredith Martin: Great, okay, just curious.

Andy Byers: Copyright notice, we have… this is the important part, so this is where you can put a transfer of copyright if you're doing that, or in our case, it's right of first publication. We've actually got Ohio State University's version in here, because I was playing around with it to make it look…

Andy Byers: look better for them, so that's their version in here. And what Janeway does, actually, is when we submit this, it will stamp each of the, fields, so it will take a copy of the publication fees, it'll take a copy of the submission checklist, and it'll take a copy of the copyright notice, and it'll assign those

Andy Byers: to that article, so even if you change your copyright notice further down the line, the version that that particular author agreed to during submission is retained against that particular article. So if anyone comes back and says, oh, I didn't agree to that, you can… you can pull that up and say, well, actually, you did, because here it is in our agreement.
Andy Byers: Lastly, we have a computing interests box, where they can tell you if they have any, competing interests.

Andy Byers: Oops, I can't type. It's very cold. It's zero degrees here in Scotland at the moment. My hands are freezing. There's a huge window, and I can feel the heat escaping from my body, towards that window, so my hands, I'm struggling to type.
Andy Byers: There we go. I wish I had that.
Andy Byers: There we go. Okay, so we go into some basic information.
Andy Byers: What is it, the 5th today…
Andy Byers: Me, Jesus, I really can't type.
Andy Byers: And you can do superscript in here.
Andy Byers: And they've got an abstract field. So this will also detect, sort of, pasted content from Word and strip out all the crap, you know, so you don't end up with that weird,
Andy Byers: weird HTML crap that comes from Word, they'll strip all that out from in there, so you don't end up with that. With some keywords…
Andy Byers: There's open…

Andy Byers: An open keywords field. And then we have some additional fields, at the bottom here. So, these are ones that I've set up specifically for this journal. So they don't exist on any other journal, I just made them. So if you have any further metadata you want to collect.
Andy Byers: You can create these fields, in our manager system.
Andy Byers: I'll very quickly show you that. So we have additional submission fields here. So you can see that the four
Andy Byers: The four fields on here.
Andy Byers: Or on this, section here.
Andy Byers: And you can create…

Andy Byers: Text fields, text boxes, drop-downs, so select fields, checkboxes, so you can have Boolean fields, where they have to check a box. They can be required or not required, as well, so you can have, like, a confirmation.
Andy Byers: If you want, you can have an email field and a date field as well, in there. So some examples that people use this for, one is about data availability.
Andy Byers: So you can have data availability statements.
Andy Byers: random text fields, and dropdowns and things like that. So you can create as many of these additional fields as you like.
Andy Byers: One of our other journals is a society journal, and so what they do is they require at least one author to be a member of the society for submission, and so they collect the,

Andy Byers: the membership number, for one of the authors, on this page as well. So, lots of different, things. We have one, journal where they publish, it's not a journal, it's a repository, but they publish what are called grey-lit reports. So, in the UK, you can't build, without taking up historic,

Andy Byers: burial grounds and old villages, so this company are brought in to sort of do surveys, and so they collect geographical information about the survey area as part of the metadata here, so they can then publish that. So lots of different use cases for this section down here.
Meredith Martin: I have a quick question. Does anyone collect demographic data there, or is that under this one?
Meredith Martin: I got it, never mind. I'll wait.
Andy Byers: Yeah, no.

Meredith Martin: I'm just thinking, like, graduate student, assistant professor, you know, stuff like that. Like, one of the things that I'm interested in is if the article… if people are submitting to us and we want to collect information about them so that maybe later they could serve as reviewers.
Meredith Martin: Is there a way for us to kind of give… get more information about them on submission, or is that not something people normally do? This is more of a, like, the other.
Andy Byers: Yeah, no, we have… we have one who collects some information, but it's…

Andy Byers: what was it they were doing? They're an industry publisher, so they're collecting information about… about the, section of the industry that the article's coming from, but I can't think of anyone who's collecting any other information
Andy Byers: About that. I can show you what you can collect for author. There's… there's quite a lot of, fields under affiliation.
Meredith Martin: What we need anyway.
Andy Byers: Yeah, possibly. There's nothing around,
Andy Byers: Sort of the academic level a person's at.
Andy Byers: But when you come through onto the author page, the person doing the submission is automatically added as the first author.

Andy Byers: As you can see here, it's me, it's got my ORCID, it doesn't know my affiliation, unfortunately, but I can go in to edit my details. And if you have an ORCID that works, I don't, you can click, grab from ORCID.

Andy Byers: Mine doesn't work, because I don't have my ORCID publicly available. But if you do, you can grab your affiliations directly from ORCID, and we use ROR data for that, so we're getting, if you haven't come across that before, it's like ORCID for organizations, so there's…
Andy Byers: 150, 160,000 institutions listed in the ORCID data… in the ROR data. So, because we don't have, option to pull that from ORCID, we can go add affiliation.
Andy Byers: And I can just search for BerkVik.

Andy Byers: My local computer's very slow. So there's Burkebeck there, I can just select it. If, once I've searched, I can't find an organization, I can just create one, and it'll give me the option to create a custom organization. I can just put my… my organization name in there.
Andy Byers: meios.
Meredith Martin: auto-populated?
Andy Byers: Yeah, so we pull them down for RRR,

Andy Byers: to Janeway, so you don't have to do anything, yeah. I can then fill in my title, position, department, unit, or team. I can mark this as my primary affiliation or not, and I can do start and end dates as well on there. We have found, because this is a relatively new feature, we have found that people fill this one in.

Andy Byers: they tend not to fill in department, and everyone ignores the start and end date so far. We haven't had a single person fill those fields in, so we might be removing them, because no one's using them at all.

Meredith Martin: It's kind of, like, pretty granular, but it feels like affili… it feels like, the one right before affiliation would be where we would be able to see if they were a graduate student, postdoc, assistant professor, because that's something we're interested in. Like, first authors might be a graduate student, but the second or third might be professor, and we need to know that.
Andy Byers: Yeah, that's good.
Andy Byers: So… yep, that's fine, we can go back.

Andy Byers: The other thing you can add on to this page is you can do contributor roles, and we use the NYSO credit system, for contributor roles. This is off by default on an installer Janeway. You can turn it on if you want authors to be able to select these, and they can basically select from these.

Andy Byers: One of the things that credit has been, queried about is there's… there's some suspiciously… there's some suspicious missing items from the credit rolls, like translation… translator isn't on this list, which is mad.

Andy Byers: And so they're looking to add new ones, which we're quite excited about. But, this is, one of the reasons we've implemented this is because we, Janeway, can integrate with the OA Switchboard.
Andy Byers: And what OE Switchboard does is it will send a message automatically when you publish a paper to the institution.

Andy Byers: of the author saying, this author has a new publication. And one of the things that they want downstream is the roles that those authors had during the article. So, those are there, we can just click on the ones that we want, and we add those.
Andy Byers: For adding second authors, there's a bunch of different ways. One, we can just search ORCID.

Andy Byers: And I can pull in Robert Collins, who's actually my colleague Joe Muller. His name has been anonymized to Robert Collins, but it's actually my colleague Joe Muller. And you can see, actually, his affiliation has been pulled straight from ORCID.

Andy Byers: So I don't have to fill it in, it's just been grabbed, and he's at Birkbeck with me, so… He's actually a teacher, as well as a software engineer, so it's pulled in his teaching affiliation, because that's his… the latest one on his record.
Andy Byers: The other option you've got is to fill them in manually, so if you can't find them on orchid, you can just pop them in there manually.
Andy Byers: There we get to upload our file…
Andy Byers: And if I go to Documents, I think I have a test file somewhere… There it is… upload that.

Andy Byers: And we can upload any data. These pop-ups have, text blocks where you can add custom information about what you want people to upload. There's one on the manuscript one as well, it just… I haven't filled it in, so there's nothing there, it actually says this is a test. But you can put information in here, you can also add information here as well.
Andy Byers: We tend not to block people from uploading…
Andy Byers: particular files, but we do have an option that forces them to upload what we call an editable file type, and that covers, that's covered by doc, docx.

Andy Byers: ODT, which is the open office format where it can open those, an RTF file, so you can, sort of force them to upload one of those as the manuscript file, and a lot of our journals turn that feature on, because they don't want to get a PDF or a LaTeX file, submitted as part of the upload.
Meredith Martin: We actually permit LaTec and Word. Those are our two submission formats right now.
Andy Byers: So what you would do here is you would just have the information about the submission formats in this block of text up here, and then they can upload the files themselves.
Andy Byers: Let me just upload an image…
Andy Byers: And… you can also have the data here as well, so…
Andy Byers: What have I got? There's an…
Andy Byers: ODS file, so we'll load that. So we've got a figure file and a data file.
Andy Byers: And you can upload as many as you want, you can…

Andy Byers: We can also allow people to upload video files and audio files, depending on the size. I think we have, like, a 1GB limit on upload file sizes, so anything above that needs to be hosted externally and linked through. I don't know if you have any video file submissions, or if they're mainly articles, that's cool.
Meredith Martin: Oh, hey Andy, Sarah has a quick question going back to the rules.
Andy Byers: Yes.
Sarah Reiff Conell: Yeah, I'll jump in. So for the… I know that the taxonomy is credit, but what metadata schema are those roles tied to? Like, is it…
Sarah Reiff Conell: Using… like, what metadata schema are we… I was trying to find it in the documentation.
Andy Byers: Yeah, we don't have a metadata schema, so Janeway stores these agnostically in an RDBMS, so it's not storing, like, a JATS file underneath this.

Andy Byers: It's a relational database, and what Janeway can do is, because we're doing that, it can export these in different formats that we need. So, Janeway's capable of producing, for example, a JATS metadata output, a Dublin Core.
Andy Byers: Doaj, Crossref, Datasite, all that sort of stuff. So we transfer them those at the point that we need them.
Sarah Reiff Conell: Okay. Yeah, so those are all sort of covered, and then any other ones that we need that you…

Andy Byers: that you guys need that we don't have, we can look at building those in as we need them. But yeah, we have a… everything's sort of done as an object, and this is… this is actually the list of the objects that Janeway has. So when you look at, for example, a sub… the submission block here.
Andy Byers: You can see there are credit records, there are authors, there are sections, there are articles, and Janeway interlinks these all in the database.

Andy Byers: So you can go into an article, and you can see who owns it, and what journal it belongs to, and what stage it's in, and all that stuff. And then it's very easy for us to sort of… we have an XML template for chats, for example, and we have… we just export into that format when we need to do that.
Sarah Reiff Conell: Okay, thank you, that's so helpful.
Andy Byers: No worries.
Andy Byers: It's one of the things I learned, actually. I used to work on,

Andy Byers: PKP software in my job before this, and I had a very long discussion with them, because they built OMP, which is their book platform, and they built that around ONNX, and so they were using ONIX underlying it, and they said, this was a mistake, we should never have done this. We should have built it our own way, and then used… done an export to ONNX. It's one of the things I learned from them, which is quite good.

Andy Byers: So we've got our files there, and then we've got an optional, page that's off by default that you can turn on if you want to collect funding information. This uses the Fundref database, because I'm running it locally, I can't search the database, it won't work.

Andy Byers: if I put Arcadia in here, it's gonna just spin this forever. But what will happen is, on production, you'll get a table, from Fundref that just… you can select Arcadia Fund or whatever from the list. But, in the event that things aren't working, you can also add them manually, so I can put Arcadia…
Andy Byers: In here… if I know they're…
Andy Byers: the DUI, I can put that in there as well, and I can put my grant ID.
Andy Byers: In there, too.
Andy Byers: And so that comes up there. Yeah, we're gonna… Yeah, I'm pretty… oh!
Meredith Martin: We're gonna want that info.

Andy Byers: Yeah, yeah. So we just enable this during the setup. I actually finished setting up your site this morning, did most of it last week, and then got the rest of it done today, so we can get you guys access to that to start looking through it and setting things up.

Andy Byers: Lastly, we have a review page, so we just run through, it just shows you all of the stuff you've submitted. And you've got an option to write comments to the editor at the bottom here before you submit. You can also jump back along the timeline to make changes to anything that you need to.

Andy Byers: In version 1.9, we also have edit buttons, in the metadata blocks themselves. So there's, like, an edit button there, an edit button there, which takes you back to the pages, just to make it a little bit clearer that you can do that.
Andy Byers: Oops.

Andy Byers: So, when we submit, that's us completing our submission there, Jamie does a couple of things in the background. The first thing it does is it sends an email to the author confirming the submission, so that they've got that.

Andy Byers: Next, it works out you to email to let them know that there's a new submission. Does that in a number of ways. There's a fallback list, so it will email the fallback list as the last resort, but then it… the first thing it does is actually checks by article type, so…

Andy Byers: say you had 5 different article types, like, article, book review, editorial, whatever. You can have a set of editors assigned to manage new articles, you can have a set of, you know, book review editor assigned for the book review, and what Janeway will do is it will go in and say, well, this is a book review, I'm going to email the book reviews editor and tell them there's a new submission for them to handle.
Andy Byers: It can also auto-assign them as the editor for that paper, so that the chief editor doesn't need to do that.
Andy Byers: And that can be configured, we can look at that during the configuration training next week, and we can show you how that works.
Andy Byers: But new articles come in, and they go into unassigned. That's the first step, so they come into unassigned here.
Andy Byers: And we can see our article is in the list here.
Andy Byers: And we're now looking at this from the editor's POV.
Andy Byers: So this is the unassigned step.
Andy Byers: We get a summary on the left here of the article.
Andy Byers: And it's… and it's metadata.
Andy Byers: And we can see down here the files as well. If you've got similarity check with CrossRef, you can send those off for similarity check.

Andy Byers: You can also assign it to a projected issue, so if you know roughly when… what issue this article's going to go in when it gets published, you can do a soft link between the article and that particular issue.
Andy Byers: So I'm soft-linking this, this article.
Andy Byers: To Volume 100, Issue 1, 2025.
Andy Byers: It's not a hard link, but it's quite a good thing to set.

Andy Byers: Because as you go through the process, especially when you go into typesetting, to give the typesetter an idea of what to put in the JAX XML metadata as well, is to set that. It can be changed, so if you find that it needs to roll over into the 2026 issue, you can change it later on.
Andy Byers: But our first step really is to assign an editor. So we've got our list of editors on the right here.
Andy Byers: I'm just going to assign myself…
Andy Byers: And I do get the option to send myself a template email if I want to. Originally, we had it skip this.

Andy Byers: But one of our editors was like, hey, I like sending myself an email, so we put it back in, because he likes having them in his inbox, so we put that back there. And then we get some options down to the bottom right-hand side here, so we can move to review, we can, we can accept, or we can desk reject the paper at this point. And we have,
Andy Byers: a special template for desk rejection versus post-peer review rejection as well. They're two different template emails that you can edit.
Andy Byers: You also get a little warning just saying that you have got Similarity Check enabled, and you haven't sent the article to Similarity Check as well.
Andy Byers: I got a little security warning here. Yeah, go ahead.
Meredith Martin: Sorry, how does the similarity check work?
Andy Byers: So, do you… are you guys signing up with Crosstref, or are you using Datasite?

Meredith Martin: We were using Crossref before, but we have… it was going to be one of my questions for you, is how do you guys manage it, and what should we do? Because Crossref, for us, is now… that's kind of where we've moved everything over, but we don't know how exactly to link it to you.
Andy Byers: Yeah, so we can deal with that, that's part of the configuration process. Okay. Basically, you can get in touch with Crossref, ask them to, get you a similarity check account.
Meredith Martin: Okay. And then they'll give you your login.
Andy Byers: some login details, and we punch those into Janeway, and then you're able to send articles to Similarity Check. If, if there's a problem with that, and they…
Andy Byers: And it…

Andy Byers: it's too much… too difficult, whatever. What we'll do is we'll actually create you a subaccount on our one. Okay. And that's usually the fastest, actually. We've done that for a bunch of people, where we just create a subaccount on our authenticate, we punch that in as the login details, and then what we do is… we get charged something like 90 cents per article that gets sent to Similar Architect.
Andy Byers: At the end of a quarter, or the end of a year, we total up the number of articles that have been sent, and we add that onto the invoice, basically.
Meredith Martin: Does it catch a lot of things? Like, is it useful?
Andy Byers: You do that, right?
Meredith Martin: now.

Andy Byers: Yeah, we've, we actually had one last week where we had to send, one of our journals had to reject a paper. It was a lot of self-plagiarism, actually, in that case. It was picking up, chunks of text that he'd picked up from his
Andy Byers: one of his older articles and dumped straight into the new one, and so they couldn't publish it. It was about 45% of the paper.

Andy Byers: was picked up. And so what that does, it really just gives you an indication, gives you a percentage, and then, it gives… Janeway will give you a link to actually view the paper, and it will show you where it's picked the sources up from. And so it needs a human to review it, it's not just, like.
Andy Byers: this is 100% plagiarism. You do need to go in and look at the paper and check, but it works really well. It's very.

Matthew Kopel: Yeah, I'll just chime in quickly, Meredith, and we can talk about this, that I authenticate is a great guidance tool. It is not… it is a… it does require human intervention and checking, and is not perfect, in any measure, and it's useful, and it's nice that it's integrated.
Meredith Martin: Awesome. No, I was… I… I'm… I think we would love to have it, it's just I hadn't… we don't have it already, so that's all. Thank you, great.

Andy Byers: Yeah, I mean, we can, yeah, as I say, we can simply create you a subaccount and get going with that quickly if you want to use it. And then you can also stop using it if you don't want it, that's the other bonus.

Andy Byers: Yeah, that security warning we sell there, just so you know, is because I'm the author of this paper and the editor. So, generally speaking, if you are the author of a paper, you can't access the review screen in Janeway to look at it. So, if Meredith, for example, had submitted a paper and then tried to look at it as an editor, it would
Andy Byers: it wouldn't actually allow you to override it like I was… like I was able to there. It would just say, sorry, you're not allowed to look at this, please contact an administrator.
Andy Byers: If there is a very compelling reason why an editor must be able to see their own reviews, we can add an override manually, but generally it's blocked.
Andy Byers: So this is the main review screen for Janewayne. We have our, the interface

Andy Byers: is relatively the same across the board. You've got the main menu down the left-hand side, across the top we've got breadcrumbs, so we can go back to the dashboard, we can go back to all the articles and review that kind of thing, and then we have our article timeline block along the top here.

Andy Byers: So you can move back and forward through the workflow. As we move this article forward, you'll see more and more buttons appear at the top here. We'll have one for copy editing, one for typesetting, and one for pre-publication. And that allows you to jump back and forward and see things. So if you're in copy editing, you want to look at the reviews, you can click the review link and come back here.
Andy Byers: If we wanted to assign another editor, we can jump back to Editor Assignment, and it'll take us back onto that page we were on previously.
Andy Byers: And we can see those and assign more editors if we want to.

Andy Byers: For a review, oh, what else is there on here? We've got logs, documents, and more. This is our, sort of, utility drop-down, where you can look at things like logs, you can look at all the documents, you can…

Andy Byers: Archive papers as well, so, you know, if you send it out for revision and three years later the author still hasn't submitted their revisions, you can archive the paper and remove it from the workflow, that kind of thing. You can also move articles back through the workflow, so if you moved it to copy editing by accident, you can move it back into review, and so on.

Andy Byers: From here, document management just shows you all the documents for this particular paper. You'll see them here, when they were uploaded, when they were last modified, and this is the only real place in January where you can actually do a delete on a file. So if you delete it from here, the file will be
Andy Byers: will be gone-gone. In lots of other places, you'll see delete buttons, but actually they're a soft delete, and the file will still be available here.
Meredith Martin: As things go through the, workflow, do more fields populate underneath, too? Like, label, file name, upload, modified, like, would it have DOI? Would it have…
